10:01, 30 January 2019 (UTC) }} '''Séamus Coleman''' {{IPAc-en|ˈ|ʃ|eɪ|m|ə|s|_|ˈ|k|oʊ|l|m|ən}} (born 11 October 1988) is an Irish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Defender (association football)#Full-back|right-back]] for [[Premier League]] club [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] and is [[Captain (association football)|captain]] of the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland national team]].
Originally a [[Gaelic football]]er, Coleman started his association football career with amateur club St Catherine's in Killybegs. He joined [[League of Ireland Premier Division|League of Ireland]] side [[Sligo Rovers F.C.|Sligo Rovers]] in 2006 after impressing in a [[Exhibition game|friendly]] against them. He then made the move to England to sign for Everton in January 2009 for a £60,000 fee. In 2010, he spent half a season on loan with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]], helping them win promotion via the [[2010 Football League Championship play-off Final|Championship play-offs]], before returning to Everton where he has made over 200 appearances, and has been regarded as one of the league's top full-backs.
Coleman has been a senior international for the Republic of Ireland since 2011, acquiring over 40 caps. He won the [[2011 Nations Cup]] and was awarded the [[FAI International Football Awards#Under 21 International Player of the Year|FAI Under-21 International Player of the Year]] in both 2009 and 2010. He was selected for the Ireland squad at [[UEFA Euro 2016]], [[Captain (association football)|captaining]] Ireland against both [[Italy national football team|Italy]] and [[France national football team|France]]. He was named the new Ireland captain in September 2016 following [[Robbie Keane]]'s international retirement.
==Club career==
===Sligo Rovers=== Coleman was born in the fishing port of [[Killybegs]],<ref name="http://www.thescore.ie">{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-gaa-968638-Jun2013/|title=If Seamus Coleman played GAA, he'd be a star with Donegal – McGuinness|website=The42|publisher=[[TheJournal.ie]]|first=Sean|last=Farrell|date=11 January 2013|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref> in the Irish county of [[Donegal]].<ref name="Hugman2010-11 89"/> Originally a [[Gaelic football]]er who, aged 16, played as a back on his local [[Gaelic Athletic Association|GAA]] team [[C.L.G. Na gCealla Beaga|Na Cealla Beaga]],<ref name=defy_logic_injury-hit_shock_title_success>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/gaelic-games/gaelic-football/boyle-looks-to-defy-logic-and-inspire-injuryhit-killybegs-to-shock-title-success-26686159.html|title=Boyle looks to defy logic and inspire injury-hit Killybegs to shock title success|work=[[Irish Independent]]|first=Donnchadh|last=Boyle|date=2 October 2010|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref><ref name="Guardianprofile">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/oct/28/everton-seamus-coleman-gaelic-football|title=Everton's Seamus Coleman uses Gaelic roots to grow in English football|work=[[The Guardian]]|first=Andy|last=Hunter|date=28 October 2011|accessdate=28 October 2011|location=London}}</ref> Coleman was spotted by [[Sligo Rovers F.C.|Sligo Rovers]] when he lined up against them in a friendly for his hometown club, St Catherine's.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.joe.ie/index.php/uncategorized/nivea-player-profile-seamus-coleman/344515|title=Nivea Player Profile: Seamus Coleman|publisher=JOE.ie|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He made his [[League of Ireland]] debut against [[Derry City F.C|Derry City]] at the [[Brandywell Stadium|Brandywell]] in October 2006 as a substitute for [[Adam Hughes (footballer)|Adam Hughes]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/coleman-over-the-moon-as-toffees-extend-his-contract-28953174.html|title=Coleman 'over the moon' as Toffees extend his contract|work=Irish Independent|first=Daniel|last=McDonnell|date=1 January 2013|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
Sligo Rovers coach [[Rob McDonald]] did not rate Coleman very highly as a player, telling him that he should join [[League of Ireland First Division]] club [[Finn Harps F.C.|Finn Harps]].<ref name="Hannigan">{{cite news|last=Hannigan|first=Mary|title=No drama and no sulking for Coleman – just dreams of Brazil|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/no-drama-and-no-sulking-for-coleman-just-dreams-of-brazil-1.1517900|work=[[The Irish Times]]|accessdate=10 September 2013|date=6 September 2013}}</ref> McDonald departed Sligo Rovers in March 2007,<ref>{{cite news|last=Finn|first=Stephen|title=McDonald departure leaves Sligo behind eight-ball|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/mcdonald-departure-leaves-sligo-behind-eightball-26269136.html|work=Irish Independent|accessdate=10 September 2013|date=6 March 2007}}</ref> and was replaced by [[Paul Cook (footballer)|Paul Cook]], of whom Coleman later said: "He made me feel like I was the best player in the League. It just makes such a difference when you have a manager who believes in you".<ref name="Hannigan"/>
Coleman was [[Fouls and misconduct (association football)#Red card (dismissal)|sent off]] on 28 September 2007 in a 3–0 loss at [[Bohemian F.C.|Bohemians]], for a two-footed challenge on their substitute John-Paul Kelly.<ref>{{cite web|title=Red card swings game in Bohs favour|url=http://www.irishfootballonline.com/news/7363.html|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=Irish Football Online|date=29 September 2007|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071009153516/http://www.irishfootballonline.com/news/7363.html|archivedate=9 October 2007}}</ref> He scored his only goal for Rovers against [[Bray Wanderers F.C.|Bray Wanderers]] on 17 May 2008, concluding a 3–0 win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/irish/2008/0517/231981-sligo_bray1/|title=Sligo Rovers 3–0 Bray Wanderers|date=17 May 2008|publisher=[[RTÉ Sport]]|accessdate=5 January 2010}}</ref>
===Everton=== Following a recommendation by [[Willie McStay (footballer, born 1961)|Willie McStay]] to former teammate and [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] manager [[David Moyes]], Coleman was signed by the [[Merseyside]] club for £60,000<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.liverpoolecho.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/good-deal-everton-fcs-seamus-3385779|title=We got good deal for Everton FC's Seamus Coleman says Sligo Rovers boss Paul Cook|work=[[Liverpool Echo]]|date=21 January 2011|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> in January 2009, ahead of other interest from [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]], [[Birmingham City F.C.|Birmingham City]] and [[Celtic F.C.|Celtic]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/everton-to-sign-seamus-coleman-1661881|title=Everton to sign Seamus Coleman|work=Sunday People|date=18 January 2009|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref> Before playing a game for Everton, Coleman had to undergo surgery on a career-threatening infected blister.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/story/683662/new-blow-as-evertons-james-vaughan-undergoes-surgery|title=New blow as James Vaughan undergoes surgery|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|date=7 October 2009|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref> He made his debut on 22 October 2009 in the [[UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] group stage in a 5–0 loss to [[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]] at the [[Estádio da Luz]], being beaten to the ball by [[Javier Saviola]] for the first goal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/europe/8318447.stm|title=Benfica 5–0 Everton|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|first=Oliver|last=Brett|date=22 October 2009|accessdate=6 December 2009}}</ref> Three days later in his [[Goodison Park]] debut, a [[Premier League]] match against [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]], Coleman was named [[Man of the Match]] after coming on as a first-half substitute for the injured [[Joseph Yobo]], and played an instrumental part for both of Everton's goals in a 2–2 draw.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2009/dec/06/premier-league-everton-tottenham-hotspur|title=Tim Howard's injury-time penalty save caps gallant Everton fightback|last=Hunter|first=Andy|date=6 December 2009|work=The Guardian|accessdate=6 December 2009|location=London}}</ref> He made his [[FA Cup]] debut against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]] in the third round on 2 January 2010, replacing [[Tony Hibbert]] in the 80th minute and creating a goal for [[Tim Cahill]] two minutes later, in a 3–1 home win.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/match/report/0910/everton-v-carlisle.html|title=Everton v Carlisle: Match Report|publisher=Everton F.C.|date=2 January 2010|accessdate=7 January 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100103104950/http://www.evertonfc.com/match/report/0910/everton-v-carlisle.html|archivedate=3 January 2010}}</ref>
[[File:Seamus Coleman 2010.JPG|thumb|left|250px|Coleman celebrating promotion with [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] in 2010]]
====Loan to Blackpool==== On 19 March 2010, Coleman joined [[EFL Championship|Championship]] club [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] on loan, initially for one month as a replacement for the injured [[Neal Eardley]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/b/blackpool/8576974.stm|title=Blackpool sign Everton full-back Seamus Coleman on loan|publisher=BBC Sport|date=19 March 2010|accessdate=24 March 2010}}</ref> He made his debut the next day, in a 2–2 draw at home to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1259428/Blackpool-2-Crystal-Palace-2-Eagles-denied-precious-victory-late-Burgess-strike.html|title=Blackpool 2 Crystal Palace 2: Eagles denied precious victory by late Burgess strike|work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=20 March 2010|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the ''Tangerines'' in a 4–2 win away to [[Scunthorpe United F.C.|Scunthorpe United]] on 2 April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1263130/Scunthorpe-2-Blackpool-4-DJ-Campbell-double-Ian-Holloways-troops.html|title=Scunthorpe 2 Blackpool 4: DJ Campbell at the double as Ian Holloway's troops march towards the play-offs|first=Alan|last=Biggs|work=Daily Mail|date=2 April 2010|accessdate=6 April 2010|location=London}}</ref> Later that month, Coleman's loan was extended until the end of the season,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/football/news/11728/6094501/coleman-sticks-with-blackpool|title=Coleman sticks with Blackpool|publisher=[[Sky Sports]]|date=15 April 2010|accessdate=15 April 2010}}</ref> while on 19 May he agreed a new four-year contract with Everton.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/teams/e/everton/8692668.stm|title=Defender Seamus Coleman signs new deal at Everton|date=19 May 2010|publisher=BBC Sport|accessdate=19 May 2010}}</ref> He played in Blackpool's [[2010 Football League Championship play-off Final|play–off final]] at [[Wembley Stadium]], which they won 3–2 against [[Cardiff City F.C.|Cardiff City]].<ref name="Blackpool 3-2 Cardiff City">{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_div_1/8692465.stm|title=Blackpool 3–2 Cardiff City|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Paul|last=Fletcher|date=22 May 2010|accessdate=22 May 2010}}</ref>
====Return from loan==== Coleman returned to Everton for the following season, breaking into the first team on the right of midfield. He scored his first goal for Everton against [[Brentford F.C.|Brentford]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]] third round on 21 September 2010. He opened the scoring at [[Griffin Park]] in the sixth minute, but also gave away a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] with a foul on [[Myles Weston]], which [[Ján Mucha]] saved from [[Charlie MacDonald]], although Brentford eventually won in a [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shoot-out]] after a 1–1 draw.<ref>{{cite web|title=Brentford 1–1 Everton|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/league_cup/9009797.stm|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=BBC Sport|date=21 September 2010}}</ref> He scored his first Premier League goal against his former team Blackpool on 6 November to secure a 2–2 draw at [[Bloomfield Road]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/eng_prem/9149903.stm|title=Blackpool 2–2 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Mark|last=Ashenden|date=6 November 2010|accessdate=10 January 2011}}</ref> signed a new four-and-a-half-year deal two months later,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2011/01/20/blues-secure-double-contract-boost|title=Duo sign new deals|publisher=Everton F.C.|first=Matthew|last=Gamble|date=20 January 2011|accessdate=20 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110121193630/http://www.evertonfc.com/news/archive/2011/01/20/blues-secure-double-contract-boost|archivedate=21 January 2011}}</ref> and was nominated for the 2011 [[PFA Young Player of the Year]] Award.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2011/apr/08/pfa-player-year-award-gareth-bale|title=PFA Player of the Year award nominees include Tottenham's Gareth Bale|work=The Guardian|date=8 April 2011|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He finished the season having scored four league goals, though was sent off in the final game of the season, a 1–0 win against [[Chelsea F.C.|Chelsea]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegaldaily.com/2012/11/18/everton-back-coleman-after-star-gets-vile-twitter-abuse/|title=Everton back Coleman after star gets vile Twitter abuse|work=Donegal Daily|date=18 November 2012|accessdate=18 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/news/2896/premier-league/2011/05/23/2500154/evertons-phil-jagielka-backs-seamus-coleman-to-shine-next-season|title=Everton's Phil Jagielka backs Seamus Coleman to shine next season after red card against Chelsea|publisher=Goal.com|first=Mark|last=Fordham|date=23 May 2011|accessdate=5 June 2014}}</ref>
On 31 December 2012, Coleman signed a new five-and-a-half-year contract with Everton.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/20875146|title=Seamus Coleman signs new Everton deal|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 December 2012|accessdate=31 December 2012}}</ref>
====2013–present==== [[File:1 seamus coleman 2015.jpg|thumb|upright|Coleman in action for Everton in 2015]]
The [[2013–14 Everton F.C. season|2013–14 season]] proved to be Coleman's best to date as he scored six league goals, more than his previous seasons at the club combined.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://bleacherreport.com/articles/1910773-everton-vs-queens-park-rangers-6-things-we-learned|title=6 Things We Learned From Everton VS Queens Park Rangers|publisher=Bleacher Report|first=Matt|last=Cheetham|date=4 January 2014|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.goal.com/en-gb/match/126363/everton-vs-qpr/report?|title=Everton 4–0 QPR: Barkley, Jelavic & Coleman fire Toffees through|publisher=Goal.com|first=Tom J.|last=Doyle|date=4 January 2014|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref> In April, he was named in the [[PFA Team of the Year]].<ref name=PFATOTY1314>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/27180793 |title=Luis Suarez: Liverpool striker wins PFA Player of the Year award |publisher=BBC Sport |date=28 April 2014 |accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref> He was also named Everton's Player of the Year and Players' Player of the Year.<ref name=MartinezPraise>{{cite web|url=http://www.evertonfc.com/history/coleman-is-player-of-the-season|title=Coleman Is Player of the Season|publisher=Everton F.C.|accessdate=5 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508174802/http://www.evertonfc.com/history/coleman-is-player-of-the-season|archivedate=8 May 2014}}</ref> Manager [[Roberto Martínez]] hailed Coleman as one of the best full-backs in world football as he was part of a defence which conceded just 39 goals to help Everton finish fifth with a club record of 72 Premier League points.<ref name=MartinezPraise/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skysports.com/premier-league-table/2013|title=Barclays Premier League 2013/14|publisher=Sky Sports|date=23 May 2014|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He created 45 chances during the season, the third highest amongst Everton players and had the second highest pass completion at 88%.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.squawka.com/news/squawka-awards-a-statistical-review-of-evertons-season/111807|title=Squawka Awards: A statistical review of Everton’s Premier League season|publisher=Squawka|first=Omar|last=Hamouda|date=19 May 2014|accessdate=5 June 2014}}</ref>
On 26 June 2014, Coleman signed a new five-year contract with Everton.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2014/jun/26/seamus-coleman-everton-new-contract|title=Seamus Coleman signs new five-year contract with Everton|work=The Guardian|date=26 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> He scored his first ever goal in [[UEFA competitions|European football]] for Everton on 18 September 2014, netting their second in a 4–1 win over [[VfL Wolfsburg|Wolfsburg]] in the first match of their [[2014–15 UEFA Europa League|Europa League]] campaign.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/29240782|title=Everton 4–1 VfL Wolfsburg|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Gary|last=Rose|date=18 September 2014|accessdate=21 September 2015}}</ref> On 19 February 2015, he was again on target in Europe, in a 4–1 win over [[BSC Young Boys]] in the last 32.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/31523676|title=BSC Young Boys 1–4 Everton|first=Mike|last=Whalley|date=19 February 2015|accessdate=21 September 2015|publisher=BBC Sport}}</ref> On 22 March, Coleman scored the first goal in an eventual 2–1 away success against [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.|Queens Park Rangers]] with ''Toffees'' boss Roberto Martínez praising the full-back for his performance, describing him as "magnificent in his defensive duties" and labelling his opener as "a striker's goal".<ref name="Martinez hails Coleman">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/sport/soccer/roberto-martinez-hails-seamus-coleman-as-everton-beat-qpr-319920.html|title=Roberto Martinez hails Seamus Coleman as Everton beat QPR|work=[[Irish Examiner]]|first=Declan|last=Taylor|date=23 March 2015|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref>
Coleman scored his only goal of the [[2015–16 Everton F.C. season|2015–16 season]] in a 3–0 away victory against [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] on 6 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/35447704|title=Stoke City 0–3 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Mandeep|last=Sanghera|date=6 February 2016|accessdate=6 June 2016}}</ref>
On 17 September, he opened his [[2016–17 Everton F.C. season|2016–17]] goalscoring account in a 3–1 home win against [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] with a great solo run and finish on his weaker foot.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.independent.ie/sport/soccer/premier-league/seamus-colemans-scores-fantastic-solo-goal-as-everton-put-boro-to-the-sword-35057215.html|title=Seamus Coleman's scores fantastic solo goal as Everton put Boro to the sword|work=Irish Independent|first=Carl|last=Markham|date=17 September 2016|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> He scored his second goal of the season on 19 November with an 89th-minute header to equalise in a 1–1 home draw against [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37959842|title=Everton 1–1 Swansea City|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Matt|last=Davis|date=19 November 2016|accessdate=19 November 2016}}</ref> His first goal of 2017 came on 21 January as he secured all three points with an 87th-minute winner in a 1–0 triumph over Crystal Palace at [[Selhurst Park]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/38620112|title=Crystal Palace 0–1 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Jamie|last=Strickland|date=21 January 2017|accessdate=21 January 2017}}</ref>
Coleman suffered a fractured tibia and fibula in his right leg following a dangerous challenge from [[Neil Taylor (footballer)|Neil Taylor]] whilst on international duty with Ireland in March 2017 and was unlikely to return to action until 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-injury-update-2-3306449-Mar2017/|title=Seamus Coleman unlikely to return until 2018 after undergoing surgery|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Ryan|last=Bailey|date=25 March 2017|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref> It was announced a few days after his injury that [[FIFA]] would pay his basic salary for the duration of his rehabilitation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/fifa-to-pay-seamus-colemans-salary-during-rehab-3309172-Mar2017/|title=Fifa to pay Seamus Coleman's salary during rehab|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Paul|last=Fennessy|date=27 March 2017|accessdate=10 April 2017}}</ref>
Coleman made his Everton return on 31 January 2018, in a 2–1 win over [[Leicester City F.C.|Leicester City]].<ref name = "Return">{{Cite news|title=Everton's Seamus Coleman to make Republic of Ireland return vs. Turkey|date=8 March 2018|accessdate=9 March 2018|agency=PA Sport (Press Association)|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/republic-of-ireland/story/3411520/everton-seamus-coleman-to-make-republic-of-ireland-return-vs-turkey}}</ref>
==International career== ===Youth=== Coleman has represented Ireland U18 schools, helping them retain the Centenary Shield in 2006. He is an [[Republic of Ireland national under-21 football team|Ireland under-21]] and under-23 international, having made his debut for the former against [[Sweden national under-21 football team|Sweden]] in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.soccerscene.ie/ss_gen/player.php?id=31&level=ss21|title=Seamus Coleman|publisher=Soccer Scene|accessdate=19 September 2016}}</ref> On 10 August 2010, Coleman scored his first international goal in a 5–0 win against [[Estonia national under-21 football team|Estonia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101151&catid=3&Itemid=11|title=Ireland U21 put five past Estonia|publisher=[[Football Association of Ireland]]|date=10 August 2010|accessdate=19 January 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101215203050/http://fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101151&catid=3&Itemid=11|archivedate=15 December 2010}}</ref> In the same month he won the 2009 FAI Under 21 Player of the Year Award.<ref name=FAI09>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101142:fai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1:senior-men&Itemid=8 |title=FAI International Football Award winners announced |date=8 August 2010 |publisher=Football Association of Ireland |accessdate=5 November 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100823092537/http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101142%3Afai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1%3Asenior-men&Itemid=8 |archivedate=23 August 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> He retained the award in 2010.<ref name=FAI10>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101529:21st-3fai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1:senior-men&Itemid=8 |title=21st 3/FAI International |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131106022019/http://www.fai.ie/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=101529%3A21st-3fai-international-football-award-winners-announced&catid=1%3Asenior-men&Itemid=8 ===Senior=== [[File:FIFA WC-qualification 2014 - Austria vs Ireland 2013-09-10 - Seamus Coleman 05.JPG|thumb|upright|250px|Coleman playing for the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|Republic of Ireland]] in 2013]]
Coleman received his first call-up to the [[Republic of Ireland national football team|senior squad]] in October 2010,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/1001/ireland_colemans.html|title=Seamus Coleman named in Trap's squad|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=1 October 2010|accessdate=13 October 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101002121025/http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2010/1001/ireland_colemans.html|archivedate=2 October 2010}}</ref> and made his full international debut in the Republic of Ireland's inaugural [[2011 Nations Cup|Nations Cup]] match against [[Wales national football team|Wales]] on 8 February 2011, which Ireland won 3–0.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/0208/ireland_wales_carlingnationscup.html|title=Republic of Ireland 3–0 Wales|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=8 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110211022530/http://www.rte.ie/sport/soccer/2011/0208/ireland_wales_carlingnationscup.html|archivedate=11 February 2011}}</ref>
On 29 May 2013, Coleman was named Man of the Match for his performance against [[England national football team|England]] at [[Wembley Stadium]]. He crossed the ball for [[Shane Long]]'s opening goal of the game, a header past [[Joe Hart]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.donegalnow.com/sp/article_manager/detail/coleman_is_man_of_the_match|title=Coleman is man of the match|date=30 May 2013|work=Donegal Now|accessdate=30 May 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130905110248/http://donegalnow.com/sp/article_manager/detail/coleman_is_man_of_the_match|archivedate=5 September 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.highlandradio.com/2013/05/30/coleman-man-of-the-match-at-wembley/|title=Coleman Man of the Match at Wembley|date=30 May 2013|publisher=[[Highland Radio]]|accessdate=30 May 2013}}</ref> Coleman captained Ireland for the first time in a [[2014 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group C|2014 World Cup qualifier]] against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] on 11 October 2013, his 25th birthday, which Ireland lost 3–0 in [[Cologne]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-ireland-1126469-Oct2013/|title=Captaining Ireland was a special experience – Seamus Coleman|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Murray|last=Kinsella|date=12 October 2013|accessdate=13 September 2016}}</ref>
On 31 May 2016, Coleman was selected in [[Martin O'Neill]]'s 23-man squad for [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fai.ie/ireland/news/martin-oneill-names-euro-2016-squad|title=Martin O'Neill names EURO 2016 squad|publisher=Football Association of Ireland|date=1 June 2016|accessdate=16 November 2016}}</ref> At the tournament, he captained Ireland in their final group game victory over Italy. The 1–0 win ensured that the team advanced past the group stages at a [[UEFA European Championship]] for the first time.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/i-was-in-a-zone-and-now-captain-coleman-wants-a-repeat-upset-1.2696192|title='I was in a zone' – and now Captain Coleman wants a repeat upset|work=The Irish Times|first=Emmet|last=Malone|date=23 June 2016|accessdate=23 June 2016}}</ref> He was also captain for Ireland's Round of 16 match against France in [[Lyon]] where the hosts prevailed 2–1 winners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/sport/euro-2016/2016/0626/798306-coleman-it-was-one-that-got-away/|title=Seamus Coleman says it was one that got away|publisher=RTÉ Sport|date=26 June 2016|accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref>
Coleman was named the permanent Ireland captain in September 2016 following the international retirement of Robbie Keane.<ref name="new captain">{{cite news|url=http://www.irishexaminer.com/breakingnews/sport/seamus-coleman-named-the-new-ireland-captain-753137.html|title=Seamus Coleman named the new Ireland captain|work=Irish Examiner|first=Stephen|last=Barry|date=5 September 2016|accessdate=12 September 2016}}</ref> The following month, he scored his first senior international goal for Ireland in a 1–0 win over [[Georgia national football team|Georgia]] at the [[Aviva Stadium]] in a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – UEFA Group D|2018 World Cup qualifier]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/37424268|title=Republic of Ireland 1–0 Georgia|publisher=BBC Sport|first=Richard|last=Petrie|date=6 October 2016|accessdate=8 October 2016}}</ref>
On 24 March 2017, Coleman suffered a broken leg in the 69th minute of a goalless draw in a World Cup qualifier against Wales following a dangerous tackle by Neil Taylor for which the Welshman was given a straight red card.<ref name="bbcsport24mar2017">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/39388290|title=Seamus Coleman suffers broken leg in Republic of Ireland draw|publisher=BBC Coleman is widely regarded as one of the Premier League's best full-backs.<ref name="Coleman Analysis">{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/analysis-seamus-coleman-everton-top-full-backs-1620592-Aug2014/|title=Analysis: Why Seamus Coleman is now regarded as one of Europe’s top Despite being very quiet by nature, Coleman has shown great leadership qualities which has propelled him to the role of captain of the Irish national team.<ref name="inspirational">{{cite web|url=http://www.the42.ie/seamus-coleman-captain-ireland-italy-euro-2016-2842292-Jun2016/|title=Captain Coleman gave 'inspirational' speech to players before Ireland's win over Italy|website=The42|publisher=TheJournal.ie|first=Ben|last=Blake|date=23 June 2016|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He led the Ireland team out for their final two matches at Euro 2016, earning much praise from teammates, fans and media alike.<ref name="inspirational"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportsjoe.ie/football/seamus-colemans-comments-after-france-shows-why-he-should-captain-ireland-for-the-next-six-years-84678|title=Seamus Coleman's comments after France show why he should captain Ireland for the next six years|publisher=SportsJOE.ie|first=Conan|last=Doherty|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/sport/soccer/international/s%C3%A9amus-coleman-becomes-the-leader-of-the-ireland-pack-1.2698713|title=Séamus Coleman becomes the leader of the Ireland pack|work=The Irish Times|first=Keith|last=Duggan|date=25 June 2016|accessdate=26 March 2017}}</ref> He has since taken on the role of Ireland captain on a permanent basis.<ref name="new captain"/> In 2018, it was suggested by ''[[ESPN FC]]'' journalist Luke O'Farrell that Coleman should also be the next club captain at Everton, highlighting that the full-back "leads by example and, more importantly, demands more from his teammates. Coleman has never been afraid to let another player know when something is not working or needs improvement. [...] Coleman sets the mark for the rest of the team to follow".<ref>{{cite news|title=Sam Allardyce must make Seamus Coleman captain to inspire supporters|first=Luke|last=O'Farrell|work=ESPN FC|date=9 March 2018|accessdate=9 March 2018|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/club/everton/368/blog/post/3412469/sam-allardyce-must-make-seamus-coleman-captain-to-inspire-supporters}}</ref>
